thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Lifehack: buy T05 first, then once it wears out, buy T80, or vice versa.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: This way you will learn by yourself how these rubbers play for you.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: And the difference between them is not that big so you can go from one to another with a minimal adjustment.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Depend on your skill.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I like hard sponge so t05 is my favorite.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: The sponge on T05, T80, T64 and T25 is all the same.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: The difference is not the sponge.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: It is the pimple construction.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: T64 has longer thinner pimples with more space between pimples so the pips give more and the rubber feels softer.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: T05 pimples are a little shorter, thicker, and closer together so the rubber feels harder.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But even the rubber in the topsheet is the same.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Just the pimple construction is different.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I won't comment on T25; but T05, T80 and T64 are all great rubbers.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: There are people whose game and style of play may work with one of them slightly better than the others.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But they are all really great rubbers.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: To sum the info up simply:

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: 1) T05: Slower, More Spin, Higher Throw Angle.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: 2) T64: Faster, Less Spin, Lower Throw Angle.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: So do you want a bigger arc, more spin to spin the person off the table but a little sacrifice in speed?

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Or do you want lower shots that don't come up as much and are faster.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: But with an amount of spin that is easier to counter.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Or do you want to be half way in between the two extremes?

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: I go with slower and more spin every time.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 vs Tenergy 80
reply_split: Especially since T05 is more than fast enough.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy has a slightly higher throw angle than Baracuda, so looping heavy chops may be a little bit easier, with a greater arc on the ball.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: However, Baracuda still has a medium-high throw so they're both perfectly fine for looping.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: In my personal opinion, Baracuda has more spin than Tenergy, however it lacks a little bit of power and control compared to Ten.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy often has many complaints of it being incredibly heavy per sheet, but many reviews say it is worth it.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ultimately, with a heavier top-sheet comes more power, but you can adjust this with your sponge layer.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Baracuda is not as heavy, but in my opinion, just as good.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy 05 reacts quite a bit to topspin, although if you have an ALL blade, it should be fine.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Baracuda is very good with incoming spin, and would be fine with any blade.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Just remember to keep your bat angle low.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy has many complaints of it being non-durable.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Some reviewers claim that with only a few days of playing with it, obvious cracks were in the rubber on the side.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Just don't throw it around on the table.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Maybe because the topsheet is a little bit harder.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: I can't really comment how easy either one is to use, since they're suited for different playing styles.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Tenergy is noticeably faster than Baracuda, though not quite as spinny.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: If driving's your thing, use Tenergy.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: If long, spinny rallies is how you tend to lean towards, Baracuda would be a better rubber.

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: In conclusion,

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten has higher throw angle

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten is heavier

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Ten is more sensitive to incoming topspin, though can be adjusted with blade or sponge layer

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: Bara is much more durable (according to reviewers)

thread_title: Tenenergy 05 vs Donic Baracuda
reply_split: I also personally think that Baracuda is a much better rubber in terms of worth for money.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: Well they are certainly not inferior products.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: So if that takes your mind off the idea of "if there are better stuff out there", it will let you perform your best.But, at the end of the day, ALL rubbers are energy dissipating material.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: If your swing speed approaches or exceeds 20 m/s, all rubbers will produce roughly the same speed.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: However, in all "sub-optimal strokes" some rubbers can generate more speed/spin.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: That being said, I can convince myself that there are other rubbers which generate more rebound or more spin than Tenergy 05 on less than perfect strokes.Feel on the other hand is more subtle.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: If you look at the older OOAK resources of topsheet/sponge hardness measurements, you can approximate the same feel with many different rubber types.

thread_title: Are Tenergy/Dignics rubbers really the best?
reply_split: Again, that being said, rubber manufacturing is not very precise (tenergy included), so one sheets might feel different than another of the same model...Take what you need to help you move on.

thread_title: Opinions about Tibhar MX-S for FH or BH

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Jap style rubbers, for example Palio AK47 red or blue, would spin your ball not less than tacky STN, but these are just "grippy" top sheets and not sticky at all.Sure you know it better than me that tackiness in Chinese classic rubbers is to compensate for the otherwise short dwell time because of hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Did you notice that if top sheet is not tacky then it will not have hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: And opposite, if there is hard sponge then topsheet is made tacky to win back some dwell time.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: So what I am trying to say here that when we choose to go for tacky Chinese rubbers we normally want to get that hard sponge on the racket, tackiness comes as extra little bonus.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Our playing style then different - full body rotation, power from your hips and etc (ask boxer does he hit using hand power or hips and torso power?

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: You might be very surprised ...) Similar mechanics here.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: If we want to use Chinese classic sponge we do full swing shots to bend that hard sponge and make it work.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: There's the Japanese scale, there's the ESN scale, there's the 729 scale, there's the DHS scale... 42 on the 729 scale would be a medium hard rubber, all those "training sheets" from various manufacturers are usually 42 on the 729 scale.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: 42 on the DHS scale apparently means very hard - maybe 38 or 39 on the DHS scale is the same as 42 on the 729 scale while 42 would be equivalent to, say, 46.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: And all of these Chinese rubbers are supposedly harder than even 50 degrees on the ESN scale.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: Hi, I have used the Focus III extensively 5 years ago and recently bought the AK47 Blue.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: For a direct comparison the AK47 Blue is slightly faster but actually significantly less grip so you are not going to get higher throw from it.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: It is also a little bit heavier (but still in the light rubbers category so not too much of a concern).

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: For a cheapy with higher surface grip, try the ktl series (pro XP, Rapid Sound etc) both are almost as light and a bit more spinny, speed as with the Focus on the medium-low side.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: I always felt F+S III was a very soft rubber but Palio AK-47 blue is a lot harder and heavier sponge.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: FSIII is better and easier at flat kills and brush loops.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: AK-47 blue is more loop kill and loop drive and needs a very pronounced stroke and not very forgiving.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: I am unable to compare "throw" for either as I tried these rubbers on different blades and felt it was close enough to feel the same.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: AK-47 comes in red,yellow and blue branding and I don't know about the other 2 since have not tried them.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: Thank you man iii and lasta for your replies.I actually went and bought a pair of Gewo Hype EL 40 rubbers in 1.9 sponge about 3 months ago.Have to say I've been very impressed with them so far.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: My game has improved noticeably.They are a tiny bit heavier than the Snipe III but I got used to the weight difference very quickly.They play similar to the Snipe but offer a little more control / placement and a lot more spin.The throw is also slightly higher than the Snipe and the arc is greater too.In fact I would say that they do everything that the Snipe did but just that little bit better in all aspects.Speed, control, spin are all noticeably better with the Hype El 40.Is the Hype EL worth the extra cost compared to the Snipe?All things considered I would say yes.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Without knowing enough about your level or how long you have been playing or what your playing style is it is hard to give good advice but I will try.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: If you like to step away from the table and play loops and topspin drives then the Tenergy is a great rubber for that.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: The blade is also a factor.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: A good looping blade such as the Nittaku Violin will also be high throw so you need to adjust accordingly.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Maybe you need to stand a bit further back than you already are?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Maybe your technique is the issue?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Faster hand speed will always help the ball curve down more and land on the table.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: More brushing, less hitting through the ball.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: I am just assuming a lot of things about your game here.If you plan to play a close-to-the-table kind of game, are you saying you want to play a more push block sort of game?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: In that case I don't think the Tenergy is the right rubber since it is springy and high throw.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: You will need a stiffer racket or a harder sponge, or both for that type of game to work.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: T05 is fine for close to the table controlled spin play.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: You will need more compact strokes to adjust to the shorter recovery time, that's all.And it's a good general rule to change one thing at a time.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: So change your preferred distance now, keep the same equipment.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: When you settle in at the new distance, if you still want to change equipment then do it.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: That way you will get a clear evaluation of each change.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: Thanks for the advance.I played County as a kid and had a low national ranking.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: (mid 90s) then had a 10 year break played in local league for a season and won promotion from middle division of 5 to 2nd top (top division contained players from strong British league teams).

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: So if that's the cause of many mistakes, and it outweighs the number of winners you hit, only then it'w worth considering something else.Are you using 2.1mm or 1.9mm?

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: The blade is certainly good for looping, with tons of control.

thread_title: Stick with Tenergy 05 or change??
reply_split: I always preferred 64 over 05 for short action/close to the table counterlooping.

thread_title: Tensor rubber for modern defender-T64/Tibhar Evo or another?

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: Whats your take on tacky rubbers on fh?

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: fast rubbers like t-05 and mxp kinda hinders progression of individual technique and too reliant on the rubbers itself providing you energy vs you swinging properly to make a good play.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: E.g a small flick of wrist would propels the ball in a forgiving manner on t-05 vs say hurricane 3.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: If u hate tacky rubbers, I'd recommend the usual thing I'd recommend my friends, rakza 7, xiom vega pro ( I myself am getting vega asia soon) , personally haven't tried andro, and the thibar I've tried like MXP is top notch but maybe a tad too fast for my level on my blades right now.The relation to high throw and high control differs from individual, but to me if i were to give comparison of it, t05 vs mxp, on loops with big arm swings t05 goes higher and easier to consistently hit the opponent's side of table, while mxp has a lower and acute angle and travels further needs quite a good precision when using it, bear in mind both rubbers ive tried were on diff blades and both all wood.

thread_title: 5Q sound or Andro rasant beat
reply_split: All in all , don't delve too much on what rubbers you use, each have small intricacies that cater to different players, and small quirks that some players like some doesn't, but with good training, given time you can eliminate all the factors ( throw angle, speed etc) of the rubbers and make it work for your game.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: I had a little look through your posts and was quite impressed with your jpen blog.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: For someone who has had little or no coaching you seem to be putting the effort into looking at how to improve.If you're dissatisfied with your FH rubber (I've no experience of jpen) you could consider sticking with the same rubber in a not so soft version - the Vega Europe.The Baracuda I wouldn't recommend - it's essentially an old rubber but for the Spin & Speed it gives it's not great on control.Genius Sound I know nothing about but it's rated at 37.5 degree compared to the 42.5 degree of the Baracuda.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Genius Sound is supposedly a very good rubber but a more up to date version of it would the 5Q sound at the same 37.5 degree.Haven't tried the 5Q sound but the 5Q is a super rubber but imagine it would be too advanced for you at this stage but it can work well for Shakehanders on both sides depending on the blade.There's also the Joola Maxxx 400 which I haven't tried.Safe option.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Am I wrong in thinking that a higher throw angle results in a greater arc+spin, thus causing the ball to land sooner (And in turn further in from the edge of the table)?Thank you so much for your input!

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: I did a little search on your blade and it comes up as stiff and fast.A high throw rubber compensates for the stiffness giving a better arc allowing one to land balls on the table more easily.Problem with high throw rubbers is control.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Most opt for medium throw on the BH for control reserving the high throw for the FH.If you're starting off it's not recommended to have a stiff blade and a high throw rubber.The little that I know of pips is that a stiff blade is beneficial.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Personally I would compromise the stiffness for more flexibility allowing you to use medium to low throw rubbers so that you can get your technique right and learn to play more easily with looping etc.So maybe another thread might be needed to see if you could use a less stiff jpen blade ?Normally with a rubber the arc starts to flatten out the harder you hit - only exception that I've found is the Tenergy 05 which I would not recommend for you given the control issues with it.So if you have a slightly harder sponge it tends to keep its arc and in practice is more consistent than a soft sponge.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: So depending how you hit the Vega Europe may prove better to play with than the Vega Elite despite having the same throw rating.If you plan on sticking with your current stiff fast jpen blade I would be inclined to use a non tensor technology rubber for better control to allow better development.I've recommended the Stiga Magna TC II before.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Technically rated as a tensor and it seems it can be used / or was designed with speed glue in mind.

thread_title: Donic Barracuda or Tibhar Genius sound
reply_split: Using normal glue it should be fine.

thread_title: Which Euro/Jap rubber beats Tenergy for pushing/serving?
reply_split: As I get to return serves all the time from all the top players at our association, the spinniest serves and pushes would come from our Chinese ex-provincial members who use DHS H3 or Haifu Whale... Definitely heavier in spin than T05, perhaps by about 25%... Other non-Chinese rubbers that can produce roughly the same amount of spin as T05 in serves and pushes are Calibra LT, Acuda S1, Stiga Boost TP and Yasaka Rakza 7... Maybe T05 could push heavier than these, but I do not feel it from Zaman M. or Justin N... As a matter of fact I have never felt T05 users could overpower me with extra spin than most other non-Chinese inverted...

thread_title: Which Euro/Jap rubber beats Tenergy for pushing/serving?
reply_split: This is my completely impartial view, despite the fact that I've spoken out against Butterfly's pricing numerous times... Now if T05 users feel they can produce spin easier (and with better control) than its competitors, that could very well be true, but there's definitely a ceiling on this rubber's spin capability that I feel is not superior to many rubbers out there.

thread_title: Which Euro/Jap rubber beats Tenergy for pushing/serving?
reply_split: On loops, for example, I could clearly feel a max.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3
reply_split: Playing back from the table the two rubbers feel much the same on the strokes, with the Rasant seeming to have a flatter trajectory of the bat and a little less topspin on the ball.It really depends of your game, I think that if people are topspinning the ball heavily, the better rubbers would be the T05 or T64 compared to the Rasant.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3

thread_title: Hexer hd vs Xiom Omega 4 pro/asia

thread_title: Hexer hd vs Xiom Omega 4 pro/asia
reply_split: It is a touch too fast especially on a carbon blade and needs solid technique.

thread_title: Hexer hd vs Xiom Omega 4 pro/asia
reply_split: The throw while blocking is low which is great and it is relatively insensitive to incoming spin.You could think of it as a Hexer HD with a touch softer and grippier topsheet, a softer sponge , more speed and spin.Like HD you really have to get some bat speed going and engage the sponge is you want that crazy spin.I use OIV Pro on my BH in max thickness.
